There are 3 circumstances under which Syria will hold UN-backed elections: 
Bashar al-Assad willingly holds them, Bashar al-Assad (somewhat unwillingly) holds them as part of a deal to stay in power, or Bashar al-Assad's government is toppled. Bashar al-Assad just put his face on the currency. That doubles down (or quadruples down at this point) on the assertion that he's not interested in hosting UN-backed elections willingly. 
A negotiation that would bring on UN-backed elections seems unlikely now as Tillerson has signaled that the US will leave the Syrian negotiation in the hands of the Russians - and the Russians seem content with the status quo. 
I feel that the most likely route to UN-backed election is the ouster of Bashar al-Assad. There's a small chance of that as there's a lack of consensus in pursuing even among the Western countries.

The Syrian civil war seems to getting closer to an end, but is still not over. Syria held elections for Parliament in 2016 (next due in 2020) and for the President in 2014 (next due 2017). None of the current major outside actors (Russia, Iran and Turkey) that are involved in peace talks are that keen on totally free elections (they prefer elections where the government first chooses who is suitable to take part and then insures that the media feeds the voters the correct message) so I think they would be happy to take the view that Assad is already the legitimate president. Since the November 2015 UN-backed peace talks which called for new elections the world has moved on. The US influence in Syria has further declined and in any case the US will shortly have a President who believes that elections can be rigged, if they can be rigged in the US, why bother with elections in places like Syria where rigging elections goes without saying. The UN will probably become less concerned about elections because the balance of the Permanent Members of the Security Council is changing. China does not believe in elections at all, Russia believes in tightly controlled elections, the USA thinks elections are probably rigged, the UK is desperate to be friends with the US because it's no longer friends with EU countries, France could be the last liberal democracy left, or it could be run by another right wing realist who is friends with Russia.

I'm really not sure whether Syria will be a viable nation by this time next year, or what exactly a Syrian government might have rule over. Even assuming that ISIS is given the boot in the next 10-12 months, there are still very serious and complicated issues to be dealt with regarding Kurdish and Turkish claims on bits of territory. 
Infrastructure is likely to be a shambles and organizing anything remotely free and fair will be arduous, if not impossible. 
And then there is the small matter of finding candidates who will be satisfactory to Sunnis and Shi'as, Americans and Russians, Turks and Kurds. 
Maybe I'll be proven wrong and elections will go ahead, but only through the rosiest of tinted glasses can we hope to see them achieving anything.

Violence in Syria has intensified and the war has been going on for almost 5 and a half years. In my view, there is no way that all sides will come to an agreement to hold UN backed elections before Jan 1 2018.

If the civil war is still continuing throughout 2017 a UN backed election would (presumably) not be possible or serve any purpose. If the civil war were over and Asad had won its unlikely that he would be willing to hold an election that would be considered free and fair by the western powers in the UN and so they would not back it. To hold a UN-backed election there would need to be peace and enough stability for candidates with differing views to be able to stand and campaign and for voters to be able to freely select who they wanted to vote for. None of the countries that support the Syrian government (Russia, Iran) hold totally and free and fair elections themselves so its unlikely that they would support UN-backed elections, unless it was the only option. It is just possible that the western powers would (via the UN) agree to elections that were not free and fair (i.e. managed, limited range of candidates etc.) in order to be able to wash their hands of the Syrian problem. This is more likely if Trump were to be US President and Le Pen were to be French President (populists tend to be more comfortable with non-democratic governments) - Russia and China clearly are not fans of free and fair elections and that makes 4 out of the 5 Permanent Members of the UN Security Council.

The United States has lost its decision-space-advantage in the MENA region. U.S.
defense decision-making frames and processes are simply no match for MENA’s diverse
security challenges and their profound complexity. The two features combined create an
uncertain strategic planning environment that highlights in sharp relief the risk dilemmas
presented by both action and inaction as they relate to the region. MENA is gray
precisely because it is impossible to identify, focus on, and pace against a well-defined
and manageable set of defense-relevant challenges. In MENA, the environment and the
trends driving it are in fact the principal adversaries.
Complexity in the MENA region means that any U.S. action has the potential to
create even greater challenges for the United States and its partners. Further, the wide
diversity of threat types makes first order prioritization challenging for senior decisionmakers.
MENA boasts a potential nuclear power with a penchant for destabilizing regional
proxy wars; a series of state-killing civil conflicts; myriad extremist groups that
emerge from and thrive on endemic regional instability; and generalized rejectionist
trends that fast undermine the authority and reach of even the region’s most capable
states. Action against one or more of these will inevitably affect the nature and magnitude
of risk associated with others.
The 2003 U.S.-led invasion of Iraq is the first of many clear examples in this regard.
In large measure, there is an expert consensus that the United States is where it is in Iraq
and Syria precisely because of the deliberate collapse of Saddam Hussein’s regime.197 On
a smaller scale, Libya and Yemen also demonstrate the risk of U.S. action. In a desire to
improve its position, U.S. actions contributed to a collapse of both Libya and Yemen.
This collapse led to a security vacuum followed by rampant instability.
A newfound U.S. Government appreciation of the risks of action have led it at times
to embrace inaction or limited action in the region. In Syria, many perceive that U.S.
inaction allowed the situation to worsen.198 Further, it opened new unhelpful operating
space for U.S. adversaries. Russia and Iran, for example, are perceived to have seized
on U.S. hesitation to more actively aid the Assad regime.199 Similarly, many argue that
American passivity in the face of increasing violence and instability in Iraq between
2010-2014 highlight the hazards of inaction as well. During that period, a more assertive

The number of hurdles to cross to get to elections -- ceasefire, actual security, political agreement on process, voter lists/registration, etc. -- is simply too great for the time frame involved.  In Iraq, it took well over about a year from the decision to move to elections to hold them.  In Afghanistan, it took fourteen months from the seating of the transitional government and ten months from the adoption of a new constitution.  Syria is a far, far more challenging environment than either of those two countries.

I actually think there is a fairly good chance that there will be UN-backed elections in Syria by 2018 since the security council resolution was passed in Dec 2015.  Yes, this is a very complex situation, but I believe there are several powerful underlying reasons why this will likely happen.  Although Putin certainly has been toying with us and has no interest in supporting our interests, he has what I believe is a very strong desire to be viewed on the world stage as a first-world, global power broker (see all his current military actions), and that bringing Assad to the table would greatly inform this perception in his mind.  Putin has also expressed willingness to bring opposition groups into the discussions.  I suspect this is because he knows that he will be able to ensure that Assad can run in the election and likely is confident that he (and Assad) can control the election results in their favor.  This is a win all around for Putin as he can ensure Assad remains in power and look like the global power broker (as he greatly desires) at the same time, all under the guise of a UN-backed free and open election.  I believe that Putin is the most important figure in this situation, so for the reasons enumerated above, I believe it is more likely than not that the elections will occur by Jan 1, 2018, despite my personal lack of enthusiasm for the generally ineffectual United Nations. 75% chance it will happen, 25% it won't because the region is still highly volatile with many competing interests.
